content: Hi, I recently worked throught the first few chapters of Mathematics in Lean. I am interested in contributing to Mathlib, particularly either geometry (smooth manifolds/ Riemannian geometry) or Real/Functional analysis ( Measure Theory/L^p spaces/ Sobolev Spaces /Theory of Distributions etc.) or Probability Theory. How should I go about this?
This topic was moved here from #new members > Interested in contributing to Mathlib by Rahul Sahjwani.

Welcome! Add your GitHub username to your Zulip profile if you don't mind, and then a maintainer will invite you to be able to push to mathlib branches. (An expert in one of those domains may also come along and have some advice on what needs doing)

If you're fealing up for it, I recently wanted the duality between docs#MeasureTheory.Lp for H√∂lder conjugate exponents (and of course the one-directional special case for 1 and ‚àû). We have the natural map into the dual space, but not the fact that it is surjective.
Hi Julian! Thank you for the response! I have added my github account to my username.
Hi Jireh! I would happy to do that! how do I get started? anything that you need from me?

Rahul, the first step would be to use MeasureTheory.Mem‚Ñíp.mul to construct the natural map I mentioned (I lied slightly, we don't actually have the map, just H√∂lder's inequality which allows you to write the function).

You should use this to define a function docs#MeasureTheory.Lp ùïú p Œº to docs#NormedSpace.dual (MeasureTheory.Lp ùïú q Œº). You can bundle this into a continuous linear map. You can show it is in fact an isometry for RCLike ùïú. So you can build a docs#LinearIsometry (with notation ‚Üí‚Çó·µ¢[ùïú].

Finally, you need to show this is surjective, which is the hardest part. Here I would try to look for some proofs on paper and then ask to see which is the easiest to formalize. It would be possible to construct a measure and then go via the Radon-Nikodym derivative, but I'm not sure that's the easiest way.
Thanks Jireh for the quick reply! So I imagine I should do all of this in my own fork of Mathlib and once I'm done get back to you? Is that correct?

Essentially yes, although you're welcome to ask questions on Zulip. Also, note that Mathlib doesn't currently accept PRs from forks due to some limitations of CI. So, when you have something you want to PR, you'll need to ask for write permission to Mathlib.
Ok Sounds good! Thank you for your time!

To be clear, you shoudn't have to construct the measure by hand, as we have the Riesz-Markov-Kakutani theorem, or at least, it's in a few PRs which will hopefully land sometime in the near future (among these are #20040 and #12290)
